column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Travel health kit
#Text=A travel health kit should preferrably be carried by travellers .
#Text=For broader discussion of health issues , see Stay healthy .
#Text=Understand

#Text=You may not be able to purchase , or even require all the items on this list ( depending on where you are and where you are travelling ) , and in some cases you may need a doctor 's prescription to avoid having the items confiscated by border police or customs officers if your bags are inspected .
#Text=If in doubt , consult a competent medical professional for advice .
#Text=Many people have different ideas on what is necessary for them - some people take more , others are better at improvisation .
#Text=Our articles Tropical diseases and Tips for travel in developing countries have additional information relevant to some travelers .
#Text=Stay healthy
#Text=Regular medication : If you are on any regular medication , take a good supply with you , together with a copy of the prescription .
#Text=Make sure it 's carried in hand luggage on planes .
#Text=The prescription will help if you do need to replace it , or if customs are unsure what it is .
#Text=Antidiarrhea :
#Text=Loperamide ( e.g. Imodium ) is the most common form of anti-diarrheal medicine for over-the-counter use .
#Text=Never use it if there is blood in the feces - this could be an indication of something much more serious and requires immediate medical attention .
#Text=see also Travellers ' diarrhea .
#Text=Anti-inflammatory : Ibuprofen ( e.g. Nurofen ) is good both as an anti-inflammatory and also as a general analgesic ( pain killer ) .
#Text=Other people prefer to use Paracetamol ( acetaminophen ) , or an Aspirin/Paracetamol combination .
#Text=Sunscreen : You are likely more exposed to the sun when traveling than during your normal routine back home .
#Text=Sun burn can cause high discomfort and fatigue which is mostly avoidable with sunscreen ( and a hat ) .
#Text=An after-sun lotion containing aloe might help too .
#Text=See also Sunburn and sun protection .
#Text=Adhesive bandages :
#Text=Open cuts can become infected , especially when traveling .
#Text=Clean the cut , cover up and continue your travels .
#Text=Also useful for covering blisters on your feet .
#Text=Anti-bacterial : Neosporin , for example , handy to have for treating popped blisters , cuts , and burns once they have cooled ; this will help to prevent infections .

#Text=An alternative which can be bought in most destinations is hydrogen peroxide solution , but be sure to get the 3 % mix normally used in first aid not the somewhat dangerous 15 % mix used by dentists .
#Text=Insect repellent : Insect bites can cause discomfort , but also potentially infection and disease as well .
#Text=Plan ahead , as in many areas where mosquitoes and other insects are a significant problem , effective DEET-based repellents cannot be bought locally .
#Text=Condoms : HIV and hepatitis are much more common in some parts of the world , and unprotected sex with an unfamiliar partner is highly risky anywhere — and much riskier without a condom .
#Text=Female travelers who use contraceptive pills should also carry condoms as even minor stomach upsets can decrease the pill 's effectiveness .

#Text=Proof of your health insurance coverage : Even if you 're only taking a day trip across the border of a friendly country , the insured health care at your destination will not be the same as it is at home .
#Text=Purchase the best health , life and disability coverage that you can afford , and keep a copy of the insurance details in your travel health kit along with your other health information .
#Text=Of course in the European Union you 'll mostly be covered across the border as well .
#Text=Off the beaten path
#Text=If you are going away from major towns and cities where medical help may not be accessible , you might like to consider taking a more complete first aid kit .
#Text=Make sure you have the knowledge to use it , too !
#Text=Consider water purification tables , sterile sets , and so on .
#Text=Also , travelers may wish to take a comprehensive first aid course if traveling for an extended amount of time in a rural area .
#Text=The knowledge from courses such as Wilderness First Aid or Wilderness First Responder can come in handy when away from hospitals .
#Text=Stay legal
#Text=Many countries and venues restrict the carrying of knives , scissors and other sharp objects which might be included in a travel health kit .
#Text=Countries with harsh anti-drug laws might outlaw painkillers and other medication .
#Text=See also
#Text=Hygiene and body care
#Text=Medication
